thread.title: Hulu Is Not Looking to Expand into International Markets - Yahoo Finance
thread.title_full: Hulu Is Not Looking to Expand into International Markets - Yahoo Finance

author: Shirley Pelts
title: Hulu Is Not Looking to Expand into International Markets - Yahoo Finance
text:
Must-Know News Updates in the Media Sector 
( Continued from Prior Part )
Shying away from international markets On October 5, 2015, the CEO (chief executive officer) of Hulu, Mike Hopkins, said at an industry conference in Cannes, France, that Hulu was not looking at expanding into international markets anytime soon.
Hulu is jointly owned by NBCUniversal (CMCSA), 21 st Century Fox (FOXA), and the Walt Disney Company (DIS). Hulu competes with another OTT (over-the-top) operator, Netflix (NFLX), that is rapidly expanding into international markets including Europe and Asia.
In September this year, Hulu started offering an ad-free option plan for its users priced at $11.99 per month. Currently, Hulu’s free service is ad-supported, while its $7.99 per month service provides content with fewer ads.

The above chart indicates the ad-free subscription price for Hulu and the subscription prices for Netflix and Amazon’s (AMZN) Prime Instant Video service. While Amazon’s Prime Instant Video service is the cheapest at $8 per month, Netflix is still more popular. Hulu is trying to catch up with Netflix in this regard.
Why Hulu won’t expand internationally One of the reasons Hulu has lagged behind Netflix is its lack of original content. Lack of original content could also be the reason that Hulu may be hesitant to expand internationally. It would not be able to gain subscribers rapidly abroad if its content was not popular among users.
However, Hulu is also acquiring original content and acquiring exclusive SVOD (subscription video-on-demand) rights. Earlier this year, it acquired exclusive SVOD rights to a variety of programming from Turner Broadcasting (TWX).
Another reason that Hulu is not looking at international markets could be a pricing issue. Hulu entered Japan a few years back, but it had to sell off the Japanese service, as it was priced too highly in the Japanese market.
You can gain a diversified exposure to Comcast by investing in the PowerShares QQQ Trust Series 1 ETF (QQQ), which holds 2.6% of the stock.
